items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message: This flood alert has been removed. The flood forecast has improved. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area this morning. Further rain is forecast this afternoon and and overnight. We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Amy today, 03/10/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow, Saturday 04/10/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the East of Normanby. Rainfall is expected throughout the day and overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive, or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 05:15am on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
River levels are rising due to heavy rainfall today, Friday 03/10/2025, as a result of Storm Amy. Flooding is possible from the evening and overnight into tomorrow morning, Saturday 04/10/2025. 
We are expecting flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Calder. As the storm persists, it is possible that we may need to issue flood warnings. We are closely monitoring the situation and are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. 
We aim to update this message by 08:00 on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 2:00 PM on 03/10/2025.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Further flooding is possible throughout the evening as river levels continue to rise.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible between 00:00 and 05:00 tomorrow, 04/10/25. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.

Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech between 3.1m and 3.4m Saturday morning 04/10/2025. Maesbrook and Cae Howel will continue to rise slowly and information will be added to this message when appropriate.

Further rainfall is forecast for the next 6 hours as well as through the day on Saturday 04/10/2025. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday 06/10/2025.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Lancashire, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message:
River levels are responding to todays' rainfall and are expected to continue to rise through the evening today and the early hours tomorrow morning. 

Peak levels are forecasted to be reached between 8PM today and 3AM tomorrow. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated as the situation changes.

River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Amy today, 03/10/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow, Saturday 04/10/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect the River Ure and tributaries from its source downstream to Kilgram. Rainfall is expected throughout the day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 01:00AM on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising due to heavy rainfall today. Flooding is possible from this evening Friday 03/10/2025 into tomorrow, Saturday 04/10/2025. Areas most at risk include the River Aire from Gargrave to Stockbridge, including Eshton Beck, Eller Beck and Silsden Beck. Further rainfall as well as strong winds associated with Storm Amy, are forecast through today and into Saturday 04/10/2025, which will likely cause further river response. This could cause river levels to remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation and are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 08:00 on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

Following heavy rain from Storm Amy, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
River levels on the River Eden will continue to rise this afternoon, peaking around 8:00 PM on 03/10/2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Eden, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and other watercourses, from Kirkby Stephen to Temple Sowerby including low lying areas around Brough, Warcop, Great Ormside and Appleby.
Weather conditions are expected to improve tomorrow 04/10/25 and no further flooding is expected.
We are continuing to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message:
River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Amy today, 03/10/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow, Saturday 04/10/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Arkle Beck, River Swale, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Low lying land in the vicinity of Grinton Bridge, and the B6270 at Low Whita are expected to flood. Rainfall is expected throughout the day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 01:00AM on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are responding to todays' rainfall and are expected to continue to rise until the early evening. 

Peak levels are forecasted to be reached between 5PM and 8PM today. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Due to heavy rainfall from Storm Amy, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Rivers are forecast to rise throughout today, Friday 03/10/25.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle River Eden, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and tributaries from Temple Sowerby to the confluence with the River Irthing at Warwick Bridge including Langwathby, Lazonby, Kirkoswald, Armathwaite, Wetheral and Warwick on Eden.
Weather conditions are expected to improve tomorrow and no further flooding is expected.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

Heavy rain moving through the area due to Storm Amy may cause flooding of roads and low lying land, property flooding is not expected.
River levels will rise throughout today 03/10/25 before receding over the weekend.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower River Eden, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.
Weather conditions are expected to improve tomorrow 04/10/25 and no further flooding is expected.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message:
River levels are rising in response to heavy rainfall associated with Storm Amy today, 03/10/2025. Flooding is possible overnight through to tomorrow, Saturday 04/10/2025. 
Flooding is forecast to affect low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. Rainfall is expected throughout the day and overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive, or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 05:00am on Saturday 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

High tides and strong winds overnight may lead to flooding tomorrow morning.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 5:00 AM on Saturday, 04/10/2025. Flooding is possible up to two hours either side of this time.

Strong winds from Storm Amy are forecast to continue through Saturday and further flooding is possible tomorrow afternoon.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The detailed tidal forecast, for those who use it, is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 4.42 mAODN at 5:00 AM on 04/10/2025, with westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dragley Beck at Ulverston from Dragley Beck Bridge on Well Lane downstream to South Ulverston
items.message:
Due to heavy rain caused by Storm Amy, rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this afternoon.
Flooding is expected from 2:00 PM on 03/10/2025.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas and property adjacent to Dragley and Lund Becks at Rydal Road, Watery Lane, Fitz Bridge, Morecambe Road, Rope Walk and parts of South Ulverston at Low Mill Bridge, South View Farm and Outcast.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.description: Upper River Irwell catchment with Oldham, Bolton, Rochdale, Haslingden, Ramsbottom and Rawtenstall

floodArea.county: Blackburn with Darwen, Bolton, Bury, Lancashire, Oldham, Rochdale

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Irwell due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Irwell. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Beal, Roch and Croal, Limy Water and their tributaries from 6:00 PM on 03/10/2025.
We expect river levels to remain high until this evening on 03/10/2025.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 04/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are responding to todays' rainfall and are expected to continue to rise through the evening today and the early hours tomorrow morning. 

Peak levels are forecasted to be reached between 7PM today and 4AM tomorrow. 

This message will be updated as the situation changes.

The flood warning has been issued for Widdale Beck at Appersett due to rainfall associated with Storm Amy. Flooding is expected for properties within the village of Appersett. Further rainfall is forecast through today, Friday 03/10/2025 and river levels are expected to continue to rise. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one and monitor water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor river levels. This message will be updated by 11:45PM on Friday 03/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
